texts.orig: One of my toots fell into a  Fedora Development mailing list discussion  recently that was titled  "It's time to transform the Fedora devel list into something new." As you might imagine, that post blew up.

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: After 20 days and 218 emails from 63 participants, the discussion continues. A few people reached out with questions and comments to better understand where I was coming from in that tweet.

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: Long story short:  My beef[^beef] isn't about the venue, the technology, or the people.
texts.text: Long story short:  My beef[^beef] isn't about the venue, the technology, or the people.

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: My issues are centered around the discourse itself and the time required to parse it.
texts.text: My issues are centered around the discourse itself and the time required to parse it.

texts.label: title
texts.orig: Time
texts.text: Time

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: One of my favorite leaders of all time once caught me off guard during a development conversation:
texts.text: One of my favorite leaders of all time once caught me off guard during a development conversation:

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: Them: Major, what's the most valuable thing you have that you can give to someone else?
texts.text: Them: Major, what's the most valuable thing you have that you can give to someone else?

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: Me: What I know?
texts.text: Me: What I know?

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: Them: No.
texts.text: Them: No.

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: Me: My ability to understand what they need?
texts.text: Me: My ability to understand what they need?

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: Them: No.
texts.text: Them: No.

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: Me: Okay, just tell me.
texts.text: Me: Okay, just tell me.

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: Them: Your time.
texts.text: Them: Your time.

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: He made a point that time is something you can't get back and it's why companies pay people. Companies pay people for their  time .
texts.text: He made a point that time is something you can't get back and it's why companies pay people. Companies pay people for their  time .

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: Time  spent doing hard things.
texts.text: Time  spent doing hard things.

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: Time  spent away from family.
texts.text: Time  spent away from family.

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: Time  spent building something new or repairing something that's broken.
texts.text: Time  spent building something new or repairing something that's broken.

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: Time  spent doing tasks that nobody else wants to do.
texts.text: Time  spent doing tasks that nobody else wants to do.

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: Humans jump at anything that saves them a little time. We stream Netflix instead of going to the video store or getting DVDs in the mail. We sign up for Amazon Prime to save time on shopping. We rely on appliances to do work for us so we have time for other things.
texts.text: Humans jump at anything that saves them a little time. We stream Netflix instead of going to the video store or getting DVDs in the mail. We sign up for Amazon Prime to save time on shopping. We rely on appliances to do work for us so we have time for other things.

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: Anyone working on open source projects of any scale have likely used mailing lists from time to time. If you're not familiar, here's an example workflow:
texts.text: Anyone working on open source projects of any scale have likely used mailing lists from time to time. If you're not familiar, here's an example workflow:

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: You write an email to a special email address with a question, comment, or a request for help
texts.text: You write an email to a special email address with a question, comment, or a request for help

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: That email goes into a system which distributes the email to people who are interested in that topic
texts.text: That email goes into a system which distributes the email to people who are interested in that topic

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: Mailing list subscribers submit their replies asynchronously until the issue is resolved (or everyone is exhausted)
texts.text: Mailing list subscribers submit their replies asynchronously until the issue is resolved (or everyone is exhausted)

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: Hopefully you got what you needed
texts.text: Hopefully you got what you needed

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: But this post isn't about technology. You can have asynchronous discussions of varying quality levels just like these in other systems, such as Discourse, forums, Reddit, or bug trackers. There's nothing inherently bad about mailing lists in general. Mailing lists just happen to be very common in open source projects.

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: When someone asks for comments on a topic, especially a controversial one, they get a wide array of replies:
texts.text: When someone asks for comments on a topic, especially a controversial one, they get a wide array of replies:

texts.orig: People who dislike your change
texts.text: People who dislike your change

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: People who heard there's a fight and they can't stay away

texts.text: People who like everything you said[^change-likers]

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: Filtering through all of these to get to the heart of the argument  is incredibly tedious and time consuming.  🥵
texts.text: Filtering through all of these to get to the heart of the argument  is incredibly tedious and time consuming.  🥵

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: As Matthew Miller mentioned in his Fedora thread, long threads often cause people to lose the meaning of the discussion. They reply on third, fourth, and fifth level comments in the thread that often veer into other topics. Nobody can rein in the discussion at that point, but people do try. Again, these issues crop up in all kinds of discussion technology systems. They are not unique to mailing lists.
texts.text: As Matthew Miller mentioned in his Fedora thread, long threads often cause people to lose the meaning of the discussion. They reply on third, fourth, and fifth level comments in the thread that often veer into other topics. Nobody can rein in the discussion at that point, but people do try. Again, these issues crop up in all kinds of discussion technology systems. They are not unique to mailing lists.

texts.label: title
texts.orig: Improvements
texts.text: Improvements

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: The problem is not the mailing list.  It's the discourse.
texts.text: The problem is not the mailing list.  It's the discourse.

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: Keeping the discourse more organized is a good option, but its effectiveness is largely governed by the project's communication rules and the civility of those who communicate in the thread. How do we make this better?
texts.text: Keeping the discourse more organized is a good option, but its effectiveness is largely governed by the project's communication rules and the civility of those who communicate in the thread. How do we make this better?

texts.label: section_header
texts.orig: Provide the why
texts.text: Provide the why

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: I'm often amazed at some of the change proposals I see where the technical solution looks so elegant. It's so easy to maintain. It won't be difficult to test. We could implement it so quickly. This person is a genius!
texts.text: I'm often amazed at some of the change proposals I see where the technical solution looks so elegant. It's so easy to maintain. It won't be difficult to test. We could implement it so quickly. This person is a genius!

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: Then I stop. Wait a minute. Why do we need to do this?
texts.text: Then I stop. Wait a minute. Why do we need to do this?

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: Always include some of the backstory and use cases behind the change. Ask yourself a few questions:
texts.text: Always include some of the backstory and use cases behind the change. Ask yourself a few questions:

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: Why do we need to make the change?
texts.text: Why do we need to make the change?

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: Who benefits?
texts.text: Who benefits?

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: Who is harmed?
texts.text: Who is harmed?

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: What happens if we don't make the change?
texts.text: What happens if we don't make the change?

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: Do we have alternatives to the proposed change?
texts.text: Do we have alternatives to the proposed change?

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: Can the change be broken up into smaller pieces?
texts.text: Can the change be broken up into smaller pieces?

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: Include these in your original post to ensure everyone is on a level playing field at the start. This reduces replies requesting more information or questioning the value of the change based on a lack of understanding.
texts.text: Include these in your original post to ensure everyone is on a level playing field at the start. This reduces replies requesting more information or questioning the value of the change based on a lack of understanding.

texts.label: section_header
texts.orig: Intermission summary
texts.text: Intermission summary

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: When I've written posts that blew up, I took time to read through the replies and summarize the comments thus far. I do this as a reply to my original post[^self-reply] with a bulleted list.
texts.text: When I've written posts that blew up, I took time to read through the replies and summarize the comments thus far. I do this as a reply to my original post[^self-reply] with a bulleted list.

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: As an example:
texts.text: As an example:

texts.label: code
texts.orig:
Thanks for all the replies! So far, this is what I've heard
in the thread:

1. Most people think the first change makes sense and should
   be done soon
2. The second change requires some more thought based on the
   use cases provided by lumpynuggets25
3. We need better documentation to explain why we are making
   this change
texts.text:

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: This saves time for newcomers to the thread since they can get a brief summary of the comments made thus far without needing to read all of them first. In addition, it gives some of the people who replied a chance to say  "Yes, that's what I meant. Thank you." It also redirects the conversation back to the original topic and reduces the veering off into other topics.

texts.label: section_header
texts.orig: Be patient
texts.text: Be patient

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: I've seen many threads where the original author obviously felt the need to reply to every comment that came through. This lengthens the thread unnecessarily and causes you to think more about replying rather than understanding the replies. (Other participants in the thread may start doing this themselves.)
texts.text: I've seen many threads where the original author obviously felt the need to reply to every comment that came through. This lengthens the thread unnecessarily and causes you to think more about replying rather than understanding the replies. (Other participants in the thread may start doing this themselves.)

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: When you send something and the replies start rolling in, just be patient. Sometimes others will engage each other in the thread and answer your questions for you. This gives you time to read and understand what people are saying. You also get the opportunity to build that intermission summary from the previous section. 😉

texts.orig: There's always going to be that time where you need to walk away. Take the feedback you received, build on it, and deliver something valuable for people. Let the people who want to be angry for the sake of being angry just be angry on their own.

texts.orig: Every thread reaches that point where the people with real comments have provided all of their feedback. Other people just get exhausted with the conversation. That leaves the people who have nothing better to do, and of course, the  trolls . (Don't feed the trolls.)
